'''''Pawn Stars''''' is an American [[reality television series]], shown on [[History (U.S. TV channel)|History]], and produced by Leftfield Pictures. The series is filmed in [[Las Vegas|Las Vegas, Nevada]], where it chronicles the daily activities at the World Famous Gold & Silver [[Pawnbroker|Pawn Shop]],<ref>Rick Harrison and Tim Keown. ''License to Pawn''. 2011. Hyperion. [http://www.google.com/search?tbm=bks&tbo=1&q=%22have+dinner+with+us%2C+Chumlee%22&btnG=Search+Books pp 1–3].</ref> a 24-hour [[family business]] opened in 1989<ref name="Las Vegas Weeky 2010">{{cite news|last=Katsilometes|first=John|title=Pawn shop boys|url=http://www.lasvegasweekly.com/news/2010/apr/08/pawn-shop-boys/|accessdate=May 22, 2013|newspaper=Las Vegas Weekly|date=April 8, 2010}}</ref> and originally operated by patriarch [[Richard Benjamin Harrison|Richard "Old Man" Harrison]], his son [[Rick Harrison]], Rick's son [[Corey Harrison|Corey "Big Hoss" Harrison]], and Corey's childhood friend, [[Chumlee|Austin "Chumlee" Russell]]. The series, which became the network's highest rated show<ref name=CNNMoney>Childers, Linda (July 7, 2011). [http://money.cnn.com/2011/07/06/smallbusiness/rick_harrison/ "Rick Harrison of 'Pawn Stars' spills success secrets"]. [[CNN Money]].</ref><ref>[http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2010/feb/26/corey-harrison/ "Corey Harrison: Partner and general manager, Gold and Silver Pawn"], ''[[Las Vegas Sun]]'', February 26, 2010</ref> and the No. 2 reality show behind ''[[Jersey Shore (TV series)|Jersey Shore]]'', debuted on July 26, 2009.<ref>[http://www.locatetv.com/tv/pawn-stars/6388433 ''Pawn Stars''], Locate TV, accessed December 23, 2010.</ref><ref>Rick Harrison and Tim Keown. 2011. [http://www.google.com/search?tbm=bks&tbo=1&q=%22have+dinner+with+us%2C+Chumlee%22&btnG=Search+Books page 204].</ref>
The series depicts the staff's interactions with customers, who bring in a variety of [[Cultural artifact|artifact]]s to sell or pawn, and who are shown haggling over the price and discussing its historical background, with narration provided by either the Harrisons or Chumlee.
The series also follows the [[interpersonal relationship|interpersonal conflicts]] among the cast. One reviewer referencing these conflicts described the show as a version of ''[[Antiques Roadshow]]'' "hijacked by ''[[American Chopper]]''{{'}}s Teutul family".<ref>[http://www.lvrj.com/living/51132932.html Lawrence, Christopher. "Las Vegas pawnshop center of new reality series"] ''[[Las Vegas Review-Journal]]''; July 19, 2009</ref> ''[[TV Guide]]'' has offered a similar description, calling the show "one part ''Antiques Roadshow'', a pinch of ''[[LA Ink]]'' and a dash of ''[[Cops (TV series)|COPS]]''".<ref name=TVGuide>Moynihan, Rob. "Summer's Guilty Pleasures". ''[[TV Guide]]''. June 21, 2010. Page 23</ref>
Numerous local experts in a variety of fields also regularly appear to appraise the items being sold or pawned, two of whom have gone on to their own [[spin-off (media)|spin-off]] programs. Antique restorer/metal artist Rick Dale is the star of the series' first spin-off, ''[[American Restoration]]'', which premiered in October 2010,<ref name=SpinOff1>{{cite news |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/history-spinning-pawn-stars-28281 |title=History spinning off "Pawn Stars" |first=James |last=Hibberd |date=October 14, 2010|newspaper=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|accessdate=August 11, 2011}}</ref><ref name=SpinOff2>{{cite news |title=First‘Pawn Stars’ spinoff in production in Vegas, and it has restorative properties |first=John |last=Katsilometes |newspaper=[[Las Vegas Sun]]|date=June 29, 2010 |url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/blogs/kats-report/2010/jun/29/first-pawn-stars-spinoff-production-and-it-has-res/}}</ref><ref name=SpinOff3>{{cite news |title=Rick Dale’s 'Pawn Stars' spinoff, 'Rusty Nuts,' set for Oct. 18 debut |first=John |last=Katsilometes |newspaper=Las Vegas Sun |date=September 24, 2010 |url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/blogs/kats-report/2010/sep/24/rick-dales-pawn-stars-spinoff-rusty-nuts-set-oct-1/ |accessdate=September 24, 2010}}</ref> and mechanic/auto restoration expert Danny "The Count" Koker stars in the second spin-off, ''[[Counting Cars]]'', which debuted August 13, 2012.<ref name=CountingCars1>[http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news/2012/07/25/danny-the-count-koker-is-in-the-drivers-seat-when-new-car-loving-series-premieres-on-history-counting-cars-388004/20120725history01/ "Danny 'The Count' Koker is in the Driver's Seat When New Car-Loving Series Premieres on History(R) – 'Counting Cars'"]. The Futon Critic. July 25, 2012.</ref><ref name=CountingCars2>Rose, Lacey (July 20, 2012). [http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/danny-count-koker-pawn-stars-history-series-352463 "History Orders Car Flipping Series Starring 'Pawn Stars' Personality (Exclusive)"]. ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]''.</ref>
== Production history and format== ''Pawn Stars'' began with [[Brent Montgomery]] and Colby Gaines of Leftfield Pictures, who were struck by the array of eclectic and somewhat seedy pawn shops in Las Vegas during a 2008 weekend visit to the city. Thinking such shops might contain unique characters, they searched for a family-run shop on which to center a TV series, until they found the Gold & Silver Pawn Shop less than two miles from the [[Las Vegas Strip]].<ref name=BusinessWeek>Fixmer, Andy (October 21, 2010). [http://www.businessweek.com/magazine/content/10_44/b4201108281805.htm "Pawn Stars: Our Most Revealing Reality Show"]. ''[[Bloomberg Businessweek]]''.</ref> It had been the subject of a 2001 [[PBS]] documentary,<ref name=HuffingtonPost>Bourdeau, Annette (March 12, 2012). [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/03/12/pawn-stars_n_1339667.html "'Pawn Stars': 13 Things You Didn't Know About Chumlee, Rick And Corey "]. ''[[The Huffington Post]]''.</ref> and the manager and part-owner, Rick Harrison, had been trying unsuccessfully to pitch a show based on his shop for four years.<ref name=HuffingtonPost/><ref name=VegasNews>[http://www.vegasnews.com/41913/pawn-stars-richard-old-man-harrison-celebrates-70th-birthday.html "Pawn Stars’ Richard "Old Man" Harrison Celebrates 70th Birthday"]</ref><ref name=EW>Smith, Grady (June 28, 2010). [http://popwatch.ew.com/2010/06/28/pawn-stars-rick-harrison-interview/ "'Pawn Stars':" Rick Harrison talks about cable's most unlikely hit!"]. ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''.</ref> The shop, and Rick, had previously been featured in the Las Vegas episode of ''[[Insomniac with Dave Attell]]'' in 2003.<ref>{{YouTube|Gvu6APT3JLY|"Pawn Stars circa 2003"}}, accessed Sep 19, 2009, July 13, 2011.</ref>
The series was originally pitched to [[HBO]], though the network preferred the series to have been a ''[[Taxicab Confessions]]''-style series taking place at the Gold & Silver's night window.<ref>Harrison; Keown, 2011. page 249.</ref> The format eventually evolved into the now-familiar family-oriented motif used on the series.<ref name=USAToday>{{cite web|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/television/news/2010-02-19-trashtv19_CV_N.htm|title=From 'Pawn Stars' to 'Pickers,' America's trash is TV's treasure|last=Strauss|first=Gary|work=[[USA Today]]|date=February 18, 2010|accessdate=July 31, 2014}}</ref> [[History (U.S. TV channel)|History]] president [[Nancy Dubuc]], who had been charged with creating programming with a more populist appeal to balance out the network's in-depth military programming, picked up the series, which was initially titled ''Pawning History'', before a staffer at Leftfield suggested that ''Pawn Stars'' would fit better with the locale.<ref>Harrison; Keown, 2011. page 252.</ref> The network concurred, believing that name to be more pleasing and easily remembered.<ref name=USAToday/> The staffer adjusted its story-line in order to bring it in line with the network's brand, which included the on-camera experts appraising the items brought into the Gold & Silver, though she did not discourage the interpersonal conflicts among the show's stars.<ref name=BusinessWeek/>
[[File:Pawn Stars shop by Mike Salvucci.jpg|thumb|right|World Famous Gold & Silver Pawn Shop in 2010]] The series is filmed on location at the World Famous Gold & Silver Pawn Shop in Las Vegas, Nevada. Although jewellery is the most commonly pawned item at the Gold & Silver Pawn Shop,<ref>{{cite episode|title=Pezzed Off|series=Pawn Stars|season=2|number=15|network=History|date=January 25, 2010}}</ref> most of the customers featured in episodes bring in a variety of vintage or antique items to the store, which has 12,000 items in its inventory as of July 2011<ref>{{cite episode|title=Face the Music|series=Pawn Stars|network=History|date=July 25, 2011|season=4|number=39}}</ref> (5,000 of which are typically held on pawn).<ref>{{cite episode|title=The Wright Stuff|series=Pawn Stars|network=History|airdate=August 15, 2011|season=4|number=44}}</ref> Each episode consists of segments devoted to approximately five or six of these items, in which one of the staff members, usually Rick Harrison, his son Corey, or Harrison's father Richard (known as the "Old Man"), explains the history behind the object. When the buyer is unable to evaluate an object, they consult with a knowledgeable expert who can evaluate it to determine its authenticity and potential value, and in the case of items needing repair, the cost of restoration or preparing the item for sale. Whoever is evaluating the object goes over the potential value with the customer, including the expert's opinion, if one is given, often interspersed with an interview in which he explains the basis of his decision to the viewer. A price tag graphic at the bottom corner of the screen provides the ever-changing dollar amount as the two haggle over the item's price. On occasion, Rick will purchase items in need of restoration before determining its restoration costs, thus taking a risk on such costs.<ref>Examples include the [[Marine chronometer|chronometer]] in "Sharks and Cobra" and the barber's chair in "A Shot and a Shave".</ref>
Interpersonal narratives focusing on the relationship and conflicts among Rick, Corey, the Old Man, and Corey's childhood friend, Austin "Chumlee" Russell, who also works at the shop, also comprise episode plots. These usually pertain to arguments over the running of the shop, the elder Harrisons questioning Corey's judgment,<ref name=CoreySales/><ref name=CoreyExpensive/> and aspersions cast on Chumlee's intelligence and competence.<ref name=ChumSmart/> Before the second commercial break, a multiple choice trivia question related to the shop and its inventory, the cast members or one of the featured items is shown, with the answer provided after the break; beginning with the Season 8 episode "A Very Vegas Christmas", a trivia question is asked at every commercial break.
In addition to spawning imitators, such as the [[truTV]] series ''[[Hardcore Pawn]]'', the success of ''Pawn Stars'' has been a boon to the Gold & Silver Pawn Shop, which has become a Las Vegas tourist site,<ref name=USAToday/> and has expanded its business accordingly. Originally averaging between 70 and 100 customers per day, the shop's traffic increased to more than 1,000 by October 2010. To handle the increased business, the shop hired nearly 30 new employees,<ref>Corey Harrison indicates he manages 30 employees in the second season episode "Backroom Brawl", and later states the shop has 48 employees in the third season episode "Like a Rolling Chum". The [http://popwatch.ew.com/2010/06/28/pawn-stars-rick-harrison-interview/ June 2010 ''Entertainment Weekly'' source] also indicates a staff of over 40 employees. According to Richard Harrison on Page 88 of his son's 2011 autobiography, ''License to Pawn: Deals, Steals, and My Life at the Gold & Silver'', the shop had 12 employees at the time the show began production.</ref> and underwent a $400,000 expansion of their showroom by two thirds, to 15,000 square feet,<ref name=BusinessWeek/><ref name=USAToday/> the shop's tenth expansion since it opened.<ref>{{Cite episode|title=Peacemaker|series=Pawn Stars|network=History|season=4|number=27|airdate=May 9, 2011}}</ref> Rick Harrison also mentioned in the fourth season episode "Over the Top" that he was building a gym above the Pawn Shop for the staff's use.<ref name=OverTheTop/> The shop also now sells its own brand merchandise, whose designs originate from fans entering design competitions on [[Facebook]], which saves the Harrisons the cost of hiring professional designers. The staff's presence on Facebook and [[Twitter]] also ensures audiences during local nightclub appearances, for which Corey Harrison and Chumlee Russell are paid $1,000 a night.<ref name=CNNMoney/> As a result of filming at the shop, however, the four main cast members no longer work the counter, due to laws that require the identity of customers pawning items to remain confidential, and the tourists and fans taking photos and video in the showroom that would preclude this. When shooting episodes of the series, the shop is temporarily closed, with only a handful of customers allowed into the showroom.<ref name=HuffingtonPost/><ref>Harrison, 2011. pp. 70, 89</ref>
In July 2011, Harrison signed a record-breaking 80-episode renewal contract for four more seasons of the series.<ref name=CNNMoney/>
After being broadcast during its first four years on Mondays at 10PM ET, the program moved to Thursday nights at 9PM ET on May 30, 2013,<ref name=EW042213>Hibberd, James (April 22, 2013). [http://insidetv.ew.com/2013/04/22/pawn-stars-lynyrd-skynyrd/ "'Pawn Stars' gets new theme song from Lynyrd Skynyrd – EXCLUSIVE"]. ''Entertainment Weekly''.</ref> replacing ''[[Swamp People]]'', which moved an hour later to 10PM ET.<ref>Per [https://www.facebook.com/SwampPeople?ref=stream&hc_location=stream Swamp People's official Facebook page]</ref> The program also received a new opening and theme song, "Winning isn't Everything", performed by [[Lynyrd Skynyrd]].<ref name=EW042213/> The opening was replaced again with different theme music from an uncredited artist on June 12, 2014.<ref>{{cite episode |title= Who's Your Dali? |series= Pawn Stars |network= History |date= June 12, 2014}}</ref>

Keown; Russell, Wallace. 2011. p. 213.</ref> Chumlee has responded to this by explaining that he is underestimated, and points to his expertise in [[pinball machines]], which he utilizes in the second season episode "Pinball Wizards", much to Corey's surprise, as an example of one of the areas in which he is knowledgeable. Chumlee later displays the ability to repair a gas-powered toy car in "Never Surrender" (Episode 3.25), and expert knowledge in discerning a fake pair of [[Air Jordan V]] sneakers in the following episode, "Honest Abe" (Episode 3.26).<ref>Corey also references Chumlee's knowledge of pinball machines in "Honest Able" as well.</ref> As a result of the show, Russell formed his own company, which sells novelty items, including T-shirts of his own design, and arranges for his personal appearances. He sold half of the company in 2010 to Rick Harrison for $155,000, so that the shop could handle orders of his merchandise more efficiently.<ref>Harrison; Keown; Russell. 2011. pp 215–216.</ref>

[[A Day to Remember|Jeremy McKinnon]] appears in the episode "Double Trouble", [[Bob Dylan]] in "Like a Rolling Chum", and [[Meredith Vieira]] in "Chumdog Millionaire", all of which aired during the [[List of Pawn Stars episodes#Season 3|third season]]. The [[Oak Ridge Boys]] appear in "Packing Heat", and [[George Stephanopoulos]] in "Buy The Book", both of which aired during the [[List of Pawn Stars episodes#Season 4|fourth season]]. [[Matt Kenseth]] appears at the end of the fifth season episode "What the Truck". [[Steve Carell]] appears in the sixth season episode "Hello, Goodbye". [[Kip Winger]] and [[Roger Daltrey]] both appear in the seventh season premiere "Rick 'n' Roll". [[Katie Couric]] appears at the end of the seventh season episode "Chum-parazzi". [[Vic Flick]] appeared in "No Shirt, No Shoes, No Service".[[Butch Harmon]] appears in the eighth season episode "Tee'd Off".</ref>
==Reception==
===U.S. television ratings=== By January 2011, ''Pawn Stars'' was History's highest-rated series. An original episode broadcast on January 24, 2011 was watched by seven million viewers, the most-watched telecast ever on History, according to the network and Nielsen Media Research.<ref name=CNNMoney/><ref name=Nielsen>Seidman, Robert. [http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2011/01/25/pawn-stars-delivers-7-million-viewers-an-all-time-high-for-history/80200 "'Pawn Stars' Delivers 7 Million Viewers, An All-Time High for History"]. TV by the Numbers. January 25, 2011</ref> In 2011 it was the second highest-rated reality series on TV behind '' [[Jersey Shore (TV series)|Jersey Shore]]'', attracting 7.6 million viewers.<ref name=9.19.11TVG>Schneider, Michael. "Summer TV Winners and Losers". ''TV Guide''. September 19, 2011. Page 19</ref> In 2016, a ''[[New York Times]]'' study of the 50 TV shows with the most [[Facebook Like]]s found that ''Pawn Stars'' was most popular in rural Kentucky.<ref name="katz20161227">{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2016/12/26/upshot/duck-dynasty-vs-modern-family-television-maps.html |title=‘Duck Dynasty’ vs. ‘Modern Family’: 50 Maps of the U.S. Cultural Divide |last=Katz |first=Josh |date=2016-12-27 |newspaper=The New York Times}}</ref>
===Critical reception=== Christopher Long, reviewing the first season DVD for DVD Town, praised the series for its cast and the educational value of the items examined, calling it "addictive" and "a big-time winner", and opined that it is the best show on [[History (U.S. TV channel)|History]] and perhaps cable.<ref name=MovieMetropolis/> In one issue of ''[[TV Guide]]'', writer Rob Moynihan included the show in a list of "guilty pleasures."<ref name=TVGuide/> April McIntyre of Monsters and Critics, whose negative view of pawn shops influenced her view of the series' setting, reviewed one episode of the series, which she labeled a "cool ''[[Antiques Roadshow]]''". Though she found aspects of it interesting, she criticized what she perceived as an emphasis on cheap laughs at the expense of family [[patriarch]] Richard Harrison over the show's historical material, as well as Corey Harrison's weight. She ultimately saw potential for the series if aspects of it that she found to be in poor taste were curbed.<ref name=McIntyre>{{cite web |url=http://www.monstersandcritics.com/smallscreen/reviews/article_1490653.php/History_s_Pawn_Star_some_thoughts |title=April MacIntyre "History's Pawn Star$, some thoughts" Monsters and Critics; July 20, 2009 |publisher=Monstersandcritics.com |date=July 20, 2009 |accessdate=March 10, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140310172332/http://www.monstersandcritics.com/smallscreen/reviews/article_1490653.php/History_s_Pawn_Star_some_thoughts |archivedate=March 10, 2014 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> ''[[USA Today]]'''s Gary Strauss opined that the bickering among the Harrisons, as well as the customers seen in the shop, is "alternately amusing and grating". ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'' magazine wrote of the show, "Think ''Antiques Roadshow'', but with neon and far more tattoos."<ref>{{cite journal|last=Gliatto|first=Tom|author2=Rizzo, Monica| author3= Durkee, Cutler|title=Picks and Pans Review: 3 Reasons I Love ...|journal=People|date=March 14, 2011|volume=75|issue=10|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20473093,00.html|accessdate=September 20, 2011}}</ref> Some of History's viewers were reportedly displeased with how reality series like ''Pawn Stars'' and ''[[Swamp People]]'' have [[Channel drift|replaced some of the network's previous history-oriented programming]].<ref name=9.19.11TVG/>
The series has also attracted some criticism from other pawnbrokers, who while conceding its entertainment value, claim that the series' focus on the extravagant vintage items brought into the Gold & Silver Pawn Shop are not typical of the average pawn shop, whose business is predicated on individuals on fixed income who bring in conventional objects in order to pay their bills, such as electronics, tools and jewelry. Corey Grigson and Charles Brown, who own a shop called Pawn Stars, estimate that their average loan to a customer is between $50 and $100. They also point out appraisals are handled by the staff, who rely on experience, reference works and research, and not the outside experts who are frequently seen on the show aiding the Harrisons.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thenewsstar.com/article/20100131/LIFESTYLE/1310324 |title=Local pawn shops see more DVDs than diamonds |last=Nelson |first=Emily |date=January 31, 2010 |work=The News-Star |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100205084332/http://www.thenewsstar.com/article/20100131/LIFESTYLE/1310324 |archivedate=February 5, 2010 }}</ref>
The success of the series has also lent itself to parody. At the June 2011 [[List of National Hockey League awards|NHL Awards]] in Las Vegas,<ref>[http://www.nhl.com/ice/news.htm?id=557821 "Stars return to Vegas for the 2011 NHL Awards"]. [[National Hockey League]]. March 31, 2011.</ref> the [[Hanson Brothers]] from the movie ''[[Slap Shot (film)|Slap Shot]]'' appeared in a spoof sketch in which they try to sell the [[Stanley Cup]] to Harrison at the Gold & Silver.<ref>[http://nhlbruins.tumblr.com/post/6811162375/bruins-highlights-from-the-nhl-awards "Bruins Highlights From the NHL Awards"]. [[Boston Bruins]]. June 22, 2011. Retrieved January 15, 2012.</ref> The show has received 7.7/10 ratings on [[TV.com]] and has received 7.4/10 ratings on [[IMDb]].
===Awards and honors=== In 2010, Rick Harrison and the staff of the Gold and Silver Pawn Shop were awarded the Pawnbroker of the Year Award by the National Pawnbrokers Association for bringing the industry greater recognition and a better image with the TV show.<ref name=NewYorkPost/><ref>[http://www.lasvegasweekly.com/blogs/luxe-life/2010/jul/23/strip-scribbles-obama-chooses-elaine-wynn-kennedy-/ "Star Surveillance"]. ''Las Vegas Weekly''. Accessed August 13, 2010</ref>
On July 17, 2012, the [[Clark County Commission]] declared that day to be "Pawn Stars/Gold & Silver Pawn Day". At the Commission meeting, Richard "The Old Man" Harrison donated $1,000 to the [[Clark County Heritage Museum]], and lent the U.S. Senate floor chair used by Senator [[Patrick McCarran]] (sold to the Gold and Silver in the ''Pawn Stars'' episode "Take a Seat") to the museum as part of a display on Senator McCarran.<ref>Toplikar, Dave (July 17, 2012). [http://lasvegassun.com/vegasdeluxe/2012/jul/17/richard-harrison-pawn-stars-lends-mccarran-chair-m/ "Richard Harrison of ‘Pawn Stars’ lends McCarran chair to museum"]. Vegas Deluxe.</ref>
===Legal issues=== In October 2012, [[A+E Networks]] and History, as well as cast members from the show, were sued in [[Clark County District Court]] in Las Vegas for [[interference with business practices]] by Wayne Jefferies, a Las Vegas promoter<ref name="Sued">{{cite news|page= |newspaper= [[Associated Press]] |date=October 8, 2012|title='Pawn Stars' sued by former manager in Las Vegas |author=Ken Ritter |accessdate=October 13, 2012|url=http://www.lvrj.com/news/-pawn-stars-sued-by-former-manager-173162951.html}}</ref> and the Harrisons' manager, who represented them and Austin Lee "Chumlee" Russell in their television business dealings.<ref>{{cite news|page=6 |newspaper=[[Las Vegas Sun]] |date=November 5, 2011 |title=Goodman set for role as TV judge |author=John Katsilometes |accessdate=October 13, 2012 |url=http://www.zimbio.com/Las+Vegas+Sun/articles/88nzFirmNzV/Goodman+set+role+TV+judge |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130215025615/http://www.zimbio.com/Las+Vegas+Sun/articles/88nzFirmNzV/Goodman+set+role+TV+judge |archivedate=February 15, 2013 }}</ref> Jefferies, who was instrumental in helping to launch the series,<ref name="Garrett">{{cite news|page=6 |newspaper=[[Las Vegas Sun]] |date=October 13, 2011 |title=Garrett to exit Trop for MGM Grand |author=John Katsilometes |accessdate=October 13, 2012 |url=http://www.zimbio.com/Las+Vegas+Sun/articles/kw0frO9lksA/Garrett+exit+Trop+MGM+Grand |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131224120738/http://www.zimbio.com/Las+Vegas+Sun/articles/kw0frO9lksA/Garrett+exit+Trop+MGM+Grand |archivedate=December 24, 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|page=1 |newspaper= [[Las Vegas Sun]] |date=October 14, 2011|title=Goodman stays in spotlight |author=John Katsilometes |accessdate=October 13, 2012|url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/blogs/kats-report/2011/oct/13/disorder-court-showgirls-martinis-expected-oscar-g/}}</ref> states that after the show premiered, his influence in the show was increasingly reduced, and he was ultimately fired and left without his promised share of fees and merchandising [[Royalties#Alliances and partnerships|royalties]] from the series. Jefferies states that this occurred after a January 2012 leaked story on [[TMZ on TV|TMZ]] that indicated that the ''Pawn Stars'' cast was taken aback by History's launch of the spinoff ''Cajun Pawn Stars'', of which the cast had been unaware.<ref name="Sued"/><ref>{{cite news|page= |newspaper=[[International Business Times]] |date=October 5, 2012|title=Pawn Stars Cast Facing Lawsuit From Ex-Manager, Wayne Jefferies|author=Eric Brown |accessdate=October 13, 2012|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/pawn-stars-cast-sued-former-manager-over-alleged-breach-contract-842315}}</ref>
In March 2016, "Chumlee" Russell pleaded guilty to charges stemming from the discovery of an arsenal of weapons, marijuana, and other drugs by police at his home in Las Vegas.<ref>{{cite news|page= |newspaper=[[Associated Press]] |date=March 23, 2016|title='Pawn Stars' star Chumlee taking plea deal to avoid jail|author=Ken Ritter |accessdate=March 23, 2016|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/55a1a5eb553a4a74b151ede4827883fd/pawn-stars-star-chumlee-taking-plea-deal-avoid-jail}}</ref>

''[[Good Morning America]]''. June 6, 2011.</ref> Harrison's autobiography details his childhood, some of the troubles he faced before he got into the pawning business, as well as anecdotes from his time at the Gold & Silver. Also, The Old Man, Corey, and Chumlee have their own chapters in the book, reflecting on their life and experiences at the pawn shop.<ref>[[Harrison, Rick]]; Keown, Tim. ''License to Pawn: Deals, Steals, and My Life at the Gold & Silver'' 2011. [[Hyperion Books]]. New York. {{ISBN|978-1-4013-2430-8}}.</ref>
In October 2011, the Redwood Hills Financial Group issued the ''Modern Cash Prepaid [[MasterCard]] Limited Edition: Gold & Silver Pawn Shop'' prepaid [[debit card]], in a special tie-in with the Gold and Silver Pawn Shop.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/gold--silver-pawn-shop-launches-modern-cash-prepaid-mastercard-131444753.html|title=Gold & Silver Pawn Shop Launches Modern Cash™ Prepaid MasterCard®|first=Gold & Silver|last=Pawn|website=www.prnewswire.com}}</ref><ref>Goldberg, Delen (October 10, 2011). [http://www.vegasinc.com/news/2011/oct/10/pawn-stars-ink-deal-show-plastic/ "‘Pawn Stars’ ink deal to show up on plastic"]. Vegas Inc.</ref>
On September 5, 2012, it was announced that [[Bally Technologies]] would unveil a new [[slot machine]] featuring the cast of ''Pawn Stars'' the following month at the 2012 [[Global Gaming Expo]].<ref>Green, Steven (September 5, 2012). [http://www.vegasinc.com/news/2012/sep/05/coming-soon-casino-near-you-nascar-and-pawn-stars-/ Vegas, Inc.: "Coming soon to a casino near you: NASCAR and ‘Pawn Stars’ slots"]. Vegas Inc.</ref> which took place October 2 to 4, 2012 in Las Vegas.

The '''Peace Mothers''' (Kurdish: ''Dayîkên Aşîtîyê'', Turkish: ''Barış Anneleri'') is a women's [[civil rights movement]] in Turkey, which aims to promote peace between Turkey's different ethnic groups through [[Nonviolence|non-violent]] means.
==History== The Peace Mothers dates from 1999. A member of the founding Assembly explained " We had come together to say that the dirty war should come to an end and that there should be peace among Turks and Kurds."<ref>{{cite web|title= Kurdish and Turkish Mothers: Let’s Build Peace Together!|publisher= International Fellowship of Reconciliation|date=2007-05-24|url= http://www.ifor.org/WPP/Articles/May24-2007OK.pdf|accessdate=2009-08-20}}</ref> Many of the women involved have lost a close relative in the [[Kurdish–Turkish conflict]]. In the words of Türkiye Bozkurt " In 1999 we came together as mothers, whose children were either in the mountains, in prisons or had lost their lives in the war."<ref>{{cite web|title= International Women's Day for Peace and Disarmament|publisher= International Peace Bureau|year=2007|url= http://www.ipb.org/i/pdf-files/May_24-2007_Int_Womens_Day_for_Peace_and_Disarmament.pdf|accessdate=2009-08-20}}</ref> They are based in [[Istanbul]] and [[Diyarbakir]].<ref>{{cite web|title= Delegationsbericht der Newroz-Delegation 2008 aus München, Berlin und NRW|publisher= Deutsch-Kurdischen Gesellschaft|year=2008|url= http://www.dkg-muenchen.de/DKG%20Aktuell-Dateien/DelegationsberichtNewroz.html|accessdate=2009-08-20}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
They have been frequently in the news for their protests and court cases. In 2000, [[Amnesty International]] reported a delegation of Peace Mothers had allegedly been tortured and ill-treated, after they travelled to neighbouring Iraq to try to mediate between the two sides in the civil conflict in the [[Iraqi Kurdistan|Kurdish region]] in North [[Iraq]]. The lawyer who defended them, [[Eren Keskin]], was later put on trial for having insulted the army after her description of the alleged torture of the Peace Mothers was published in a newspaper.<ref>{{cite web|title= Memorandum from Amnesty International UK|publisher= Amnesty International|date=January 2002 |url= https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200102/cmselect/cmfaff/606/2021209.htm|accessdate=2009-08-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title= Turkey: Torture/ill-treatment|website=[[Amnesty International]]|date=2000-10-20|url= https://www.amnesty.org.ru/library/Index/ENGEUR440552000?open&of=ENG-TUR |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222215546/https://amnesty.org.ru/library/Index/ENGEUR440552000?open&of=ENG-TUR |archivedate=2015-12-22 |accessdate=2009-08-20}}</ref>
In June 2006, Peace Mother activists Muyesser Gunes and Sakine Arat were sentenced to 1-year jail each and 600 YTL in Ankara 4th Criminal Court on a charge of praising a separatist organisation and its leader, after they had visited the [[Turkish General Staff|General Staff]] headquarters on 22 August 2005 to present their case. The sentence was later commuted to 10 months.<ref>{{cite web|title= Jail sentence to Peace Mothers|publisher= Karawane|date=2006-06-03|url= http://thecaravan.org/node/757|accessdate=2009-08-20}}</ref>
In July 2006, twenty-four Peace Mothers aged between 40 and 75 years, were sentenced to 12 months’ jail by the Diyarbakır 4th Criminal Court after being found guilty of voicing "separatist propaganda".<ref>{{cite web|title= Peace activists sentenced for 'separatist propaganda'|publisher= The Green Left|date=2006-07-26|url= http://www.greenleft.org.au/2006/676/7647|accessdate=2009-08-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title= Turkey sentences peace mothers to 10 months|publisher= All Empires|date=2006-07-19|url=http://www.allempires.net/topic13441&OB=DESC.html|accessdate=2009-08-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title= Peace Mothers Convicted|publisher= Democratic Turkey Forum|date=2006-07-19|url=http://dtf.syncope.de/index.php?id=37&tx_ttnews%5BpS%5D=1221955668&tx_ttnews%5Bpointer%5D=24&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=60&tx_ttnews%5BbackPid%5D=61&cHash=26a3c93cfd|accessdate=2009-08-20}}</ref>
In August 2009 a group of Peace Mothers organised a [[Peace walk|peace march]] from [[Diyarbakir]] and [[Ankara]] and held a [[sit-in]] protest near the [[Turkish General Staff]] headquarters in Ankara.<ref>{{cite web|title= Pro-peace mothers march from Diyarbekir to Ankara|publisher= AK News|date=2009-08-11|url=http://www.aknews.com/en/aknews/4/62145|accessdate=2009-08-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title= Pro-Kurdish demonstrators calling themselves "Peace Mothers" hold a sit-in protest near the Turkish General Staff headquarters in Ankara|publisher= [[Reuters]]|date=2009-08-11|url=http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/pictures/ANK09.htm|accessdate=2009-08-20}}</ref>

'''Marguerite Frances Baird''' (1890— 23 September 1970, also known as Peggy Baird, Peggy Johns, and Peggy Cowley) was an American landscape painter. She was married to poet-playwright [[Orrick Johns]] and writer [[Malcolm Cowley]] and was the lover of playwright [[Eugene O'Neill]] and poet [[Hart Crane]].<ref>{{cite book |title=Time of Our Lives |last=Johns |first=Orrick |year=1937 |publisher=Stackpole |location=New York }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Eugene O'Neill: Beyond Mourning and Tragedy |last=Black |first=Stephen A. |year=2002 |publisher=Yale University press. |isbn=0-300-09399-3 |pages=201 }}</ref><ref>Hart Crane, ''The Letters of Hart Crane, 1916-1932'' (Hermitage House, 1952), page 403</ref>
Baird was a member of the women's suffrage movement. In 1917, she invited [[Dorothy Day]] to join the [[National Woman's Party]].<ref>{{cite book |title=American Catholic Pacifism |last=Klejment |first=Anne |author2=Roberts, Nancy L. |year=1996 |publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group |isbn=0-275-94784-X |pages=21–22 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RAL7LsOGrdkC&printsec=frontcover&dq=%22American+Catholic+Pacifism%22&num=100&sig=A3sj_6J7y9JyahbdqT8BBSvzhfg#PPA21,M1 }}</ref> They were jailed for 60 days for their protests but were released after 16 days and pardoned by President [[Woodrow Wilson]].[http://www.catholicworker.org/dorothyday/daytext.cfm?TextID=504]
After divorcing her first husband, Johns, she married, in 1919, Malcolm Cowley. In 1931 she moved to Mexico to obtain a divorce. While there her long friendship with poet [[Hart Crane]] turned into Crane's first and only documented heterosexual affair.<ref>{{cite book |title=Time and the Literary |last=Newman |first=Karen |author2=Clayton, Jay |author3=Hirsch, Marianne |year=2002 |publisher=Routledge |isbn=0-415-93960-7 |pages=241 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QqO7s2b6RjUC&pg=PA241&dq=%22Peggy+Baird%22+%2Bcowley&num=100&as_brr=3&sig=FEI_CEPV0OFeo4kMW8Bv1gnSXhE }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=The Broken Tower |last=Mariani |first=Paul |pages=377}}</ref> As Crane wrote to a friend about his romance with Peggy Cowley, "Rather amazing things have happened to me since Xmas. Peggy Cowley ... is mainly responsible".<ref>Hart Crane, ''The Letters of Hart Crane, 1916-1932'' (Hermitage House, 1952), page 403</ref> This affair has since become a major point of interest for Crane scholars—particularly for those reading him with an eye toward his sexuality—as his engagement with heterosexual life is a determining theme in his last major poem, "[[The Broken Tower]]". Appearing at moments to be a highly symbolic affirmation of their relationship, as well as a denial of his homosexual past (the 'broken tower' can be read as a defeated phallus), the poem was written just months before Crane committed suicide by jumping off the side of a boat in 1932, while on a trip to New York City.<ref>See, for instance, Harold Bloom's introduction to Mark Simon's edition of Crane's poems, published by Liveright (2000), p. xxx.</ref>
Though their relationship had begun to deteriorate by that time (Crane said he had "misunderstood and misinterpreted Peggy's character quite badly"), Cowley was with Crane on the boat, and she figures briefly, but poignantly, in the events leading up to his death.<ref>See the last chapter in Mariani, as well as articles on "[[The Broken Tower]]" and [[Hart Crane#The 'Homosexual Text'|Hart Crane's sexuality]].</ref>[http://speccoll.library.kent.edu/literature/poetry/crane.html] Almost thirty years later, she wrote about this period in an article for ''Venture'', "The Last Days of Hart Crane."<ref>Vol 4., No. 1, 1961</ref>
After Crane's death, Cowley married twice more and converted to Catholicism.<ref>Matthew Marcovic, ''Peggy Baird Cowley: 'Late Have I Loved Thee': Her Wayward Journey from Greenwich Village to Rome'' (St. Matthew Books, 2010)</ref> Cowley died of cancer at Dorothy Day's Catholic Worker Farm in Tivoli, New York, where Cowley had resided for ten years.<ref>Paul L. Mariani, ''Broken Tower: A Life of Hart Crane'' (W.W. Norton, 2000), page 427)</ref>[http://www.catholicworker.org/dorothyday/daytext.cfm?TextID=504]

{{Buddhism}}
A '''pratyekabuddha''' or '''paccekabuddha''' ([[Sanskrit]] and [[Pali]], respectively), literally "a lone [[Buddhahood|buddha]]", "a buddha on their own" or "a private buddha", is one of three types of [[bodhi|enlightened]] beings according to some schools of [[Buddhism]]. The other two buddha types are the [[arhat]] and the ''[[Buddhahood#Samyaksambuddha|sammāsambuddha]]'' (Sanskrit ''samyaksambuddha'').
==Characteristics==
===General overview=== The ''[[yana (Buddhism)|yāna]]'' or "vehicle" by which pratyekabuddhas achieve enlightenment is called the [[pratyekabuddhayāna]] in Indian Buddhist tradition.
Pratyekabuddhas are said to achieve enlightenment on their own, without the use of teachers or guides, according some traditions by seeing and understanding [[pratītyasamutpāda|dependent origination]]. They are said to arise only in ages where there is no Buddha and the Buddhist teachings (Sanskrit: [[dharma]]; Pāli: ''dhamma'') are lost. "The idea of a Paccekabuddha … is interesting, as much as it implies that even when the four truths are not preached they still exist and can be discovered by anyone who makes the necessary mental and moral effort".<ref>Charles Eliot, [https://archive.org/details/hinduismandbuddh15255gut Hinduism and Buddhism], 3 Volumes, London, 1922, I 344–5</ref> Many may arise at a single time.
According to the [[Theravada]] school, paccekabuddhas ("one who has attained to supreme and perfect insight, but who dies without proclaiming the truth to the world")<ref>http://www.palikanon.com/english/pali_names/pa/pacceka_buddha.htm</ref> are unable to teach the Dhamma, which requires<ref>Kloppenborg , Ria (1983). [http://www.bps.lk/olib/wh/wh305-p.html The Paccekabuddha: A Buddhist Ascetic] - A Study of the Concept of the Paccekabuddha in Pali Canonical and Commentarial Literature, The Wheel Publication No. 305–7, Kandy, Sri Lanka: Buddhist Publication Society </ref> the omniscience and supreme compassion of a sammāsambuddha, and even he hesitates to attempt to teach.<ref>[http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/sn/sn06/sn06.001.than.html Ayacana Sutta: The Request (SN 6.1)] translated from the Pali by [[Thanissaro Bhikkhu]] @ [http://www.accesstoinsight.org Access to Insight]</ref> Paccekabuddha give moral teachings but do not bring others to enlightenment. They leave no [[sangha]] as a legacy to carry on the Dhamma.
===In the ''Abhidharmasamuccaya''=== In the fourth-century Mahayana [[abhidharma]] work, the ''Abhidharma-samuccaya'', Asaṅga describes followers of the Pratyekabuddhayāna as those who dwell alone like a [[Indian rhinoceros|rhinoceros]] or as solitary conquerors (Skt. ''pratyekajina'') living in small groups.<ref>Boin-Webb, Sara (tr). Rahula, Walpola (tr). Asanga. ''Abhidharma Samuccaya: The Compendium of Higher Teaching.'' 2001. pp. 199-200</ref> Here they are characterized as utilizing the same canon of texts as the [[śrāvaka]]s, the Śrāvaka Piṭaka, but having a different set of teachings, the "Pratyekabuddha Dharma".<ref>Boin-Webb, Sara (tr). Rahula, Walpola (tr). Asanga. ''Abhidharma Samuccaya: The Compendium of Higher Teaching.'' 2001. pp. 199-200</ref>
A very early sutra, the ''[[Rhinoceros Sutra]]'', uses the exact metaphor of Asaṅga. The ''Rhinoceros Sutra'' is one of the [[Gandhāran Buddhist texts]], which are the oldest Buddhist texts known.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Salomon|first1=Richard|authorlink1=Richard G. Salomon (academic) |last2=Glass|first2=Andrew|title=A Gāndhārī Version of the Rhinoceros Sūtra: British Library Kharoṣṭhī Fragment 5B|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cTmN8Xs9xBkC|year=2000|publisher=University of Washington Press|isbn=978-0-295-98035-5|page=10,13}}</ref> This text is also present in the [[Pāli Canon]]; in the [[Sutta Pitaka]], a [[Pali]] ''Rhinoceros Sutta'' is the third sutta in the [[Khuddaka Nikaya]]'s [[Sutta Nipata]]'s first chapter ([[Sutta Nipata|Sn]] 1.3).{{sfn|Thanissaro Bhikkhu|1997}}
==In the Jātakas== Pratyekabuddhas (e.g. Darīmukha J.378, Sonaka J.529) appear as teachers of Buddhist doctrine in pre-Buddhist times in several of the [[Jataka tales]].

[https://web.archive.org/web/20120423090855/http://www.buddhismuskunde.uni-hamburg.de/fileadmin/pdf/analayo/Paccekabuddhas.pdf Paccekabuddhas in the Isigili-sutta and its Ekottarika-àgama Parallel], Canadian Journal of Buddhist Studies 6, 5-36
